title: Nick Cave's grief over late son, 15, expressed in new album Ghosteen
text:
It has been four years since Nick Cave's son, Arthur, died aged 15.

And the Australian musician's new album Ghosteen, his first to be completely written after Arthur's passing, has been praised as a 'devastating' account of his grief.

Critics have described Ghosteen as one of Nick's best releases, adding that many of the songs offer a raw insight into his family tragedy.

'His most powerful album yet': Nick Cave's new album Ghosteen, his first to be completely written after his son Arthur's death, has been praised as a 'devastating' account of his grief

Heartbreak: Critics have described Ghosteen as one of Nick's best releases, adding that many of the songs offer a raw insight into his family tragedy

Reviewing Ghosteen for Pitchfork, Grayson Currin said he was 'devastated by its despair and lifted higher by its humanity'.

'Nick Cave emerges with one of his most powerful albums yet, an endlessly giving and complex meditation on mortality and our collective grief,' Currin added.

Meanwhile, The New York Times' Jon Pareles praised Nick's exploration of the different stages of grief.

Tragic loss: In 2015, Arthur Cave (pictured) fell to his death from a seaside cliff in England after taking LSD. At the time, Nick was recording his album Skeleton Tree

Moving on: 'Cave isn’t trapped in his sorrow or consumed by it; he has figured out how to live past it, to seek solace after desolation,' New York Times critic Jon Pareles wrote

'Cave isn't trapped in his sorrow or consumed by it; he has figured out how to live past it, to seek solace after desolation,' Pareles wrote.

Despite the dark themes, The AV Club's Marty Garner said the record was Nick's 'most accessible album since 1997'.

He wrote: 'Ghosteen's simplest lyrics often have the most devastating impact.'

The Cave family: Nick and his wife Susie Bick (pictured) married in 1999 and welcomed fraternal twin sons Arthur (left) and Earl (right) the following year

In 2015, Arthur fell from a seaside cliff in England after taking LSD. At the time, Nick was recording his album Skeleton Tree.

Ghosteen is Nick's first album to be completely written and recorded after his son's tragic death.

Nick and his wife Susie Bick married in 1999 and welcomed fraternal twin sons Arthur and Earl the following year.

Earl is now a 19-year-old actor, who has starred in Channel 4 mini series Born to Kill and Netflix's The End of the F**king World.
